cards.back:
A subset \( H \) of \( \mathbb{R}^n \) that satisfies:

  1. Contains the zero vector: \( \vec{0} \in H \)
  2. Closed under addition: \( \vec{u}, \vec{v} \in H \Rightarrow \vec{u} + \vec{v} \in H \)
  3. Closed under scalar multiplication: \( \vec{u} \in H, c \in \mathbb{R} \Rightarrow c\vec{u} \in H \)

cards.front: What is the dimension of a subspace?
cards.back:
The number of vectors in any basis for the subspace.

All bases for a given subspace have the same number of vectors.

cards.front: What is the dimension of the column space of an \( m \times n \) matrix?
cards.back:
The rank of the matrix.

This equals the number of pivot columns, which is the number of linearly independent columns.

cards.front: What is the dimension of the null space of an \( m \times n \) matrix?
cards.back:
The number of free variables, which equals \( n - \text{rank}(A) \).

This is called the nullity of \( A \).

For an \( m \times n \) matrix \( A \):

\( \text{rank}(A) + \text{nullity}(A) = n \)

The dimension of the column space plus the dimension of the null space equals the number of columns.

cards.front: What is the row space of a matrix?
cards.back:
The span of the row vectors.

Equivalently, the column space of \( A^T \).

The dimension of the row space equals the rank (same as column space dimension).

cards.front: How do you find a basis for the column space?
cards.back:
Row reduce and identify pivot columns.

The corresponding columns of the original matrix (not the reduced matrix) form a basis for the column space.

cards.front: How do you find a basis for the null space?
cards.back:
1. Solve \( A\vec{x} = \vec{0} \) using row reduction
  2. Express basic variables in terms of free variables
  3. Write the general solution as a linear combination of vectors, one per free variable

These vectors form a basis for the null space.

cards.front: What is the relationship between row operations and column space?
cards.back:
Row operations change the column space but preserve which columns are linearly independent.

The pivot columns of \( A \) correspond to a basis, but you must use the original columns of \( A \), not the reduced form.

cards.front: What are the four fundamental subspaces of a matrix \( A \), and how are they related?
cards.back:
1. Column space of \( A \) (in \( \mathbb{R}^m \))
  2. Null space of \( A \) (in \( \mathbb{R}^n \))
  3. Row space of \( A \) (in \( \mathbb{R}^n \))
  4. Left null space of \( A \) (null space of \( A^T \), in \( \mathbb{R}^m \))

Orthogonal complement relationships:
  • \( (\text{Row}(A))^\perp = \text{Null}(A) \)
  • \( (\text{Col}(A))^\perp = \text{Null}(A^T) \)

Rank-nullity ties their dimensions together: \( \dim(\text{Col}(A)) + \dim(\text{Null}(A)) = n \).

cards.front: What does it mean for a subspace to be "linear"?
cards.back:
A subspace is called linear because it is closed under linear combinations:

If \( \vec{u}, \vec{v} \in H \) and \( a, b \in \mathbb{R} \), then \( a\vec{u} + b\vec{v} \in H \).

This implies it must contain \( \vec{0} \) (set \( a = b = 0 \)).

Geometrically:
  • Contains the origin
  • Is "flat" (no curvature)
  • Extends infinitely in all its directions
